paper_title.en: Cytosine and Uracil Synthesis by Quenching with High-Temperature Plasma
Fragmentation and dispersion of aluminum nitride ceramic plates by hypervelocity impact

description.en: The present paper describes the fragmentation and dispersion of aluminum nitride ceramic plates by a hypervelocity projectile impact. A manganese aluminide spherical magnet was used as a projectile, with a diameter of 1 mm; it was accelerated by a so-called ''micro'' two-stage light gas gun in the velocity range of 3-4 km/s. The fragmentation of aluminum ni t ride plates was evaluated by characterizing the distribution of fragments produced downrange behind the target plate. This fragmentation was then compared with that of aluminum alloy plates. In particular, ring-type distributions of fragments were found in the fragmentation of aluminum nitride ceramic plates. (C) 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.

paper_title.en: Influence of Specimen Thickness and Projectile Material on Crater and Spalling of an Electrode-grade Graphite by the Impact of a Projectile
Impact of high velocity projectile to carbon-fiber fabric and alumina-fiber fabric

description.en: Carbon-fiber fabric(s) or alumina-fiber fabric(s) sandwiched between two 2-mm thick aluminum plates, are impacted by a high velocity projectile up to 2.7 km/s. The projectile penetrates into the specimen and results in a perforation hole. Based on the observations of the hole, the following is suggested. The interface affects the shape of the holes, a punch-out hole is generated in 10 sheets of the alumina-fiber fabrics, but no clear hole is made in 10 sheets of carbon-fiber fabrics.

paper_title.en: An in-situ observation of amorphization of carbyne particle under electron-beam irradiation
Titanium Carbide Foams by Self-propagation High Temperature Synthesis in Terrestrial and Microgravity Conditions
Parameter Change of Magneto -Plasma- Dynamic Arc -Jet Plasma on a Flow- Facing Plate
Dendrites of silicon nitride grown in free space by a rapid condensation method

description.en: A study has been made of the growth and morphology of Si3N4 dendrites obtained by rapid condensation of high-temperature ultrasuper-saturated gas generated from amorphous silicon nitride (Si3N4) powder using a cylindrically converging shock wave technique. The obtained dendrites were an alpha modification (rhombohedral structure), a beta modification (hexagonal structure), and an aggregate consisting of alpha and beta modifications. The morphology and crystal structures of the dendrites suggested that they grew rapidly via vapour --> solid process or vapour --> liquid --> solid process in free space.

paper_title.en: Evaluation of Damage Potential of Solid Debris
CRATER FORMATION OF CARBON MATERIALS BY IMPACT OF A HIGH-VELOCITY SPHERE

description.en: Four types of polycrystalline carbon material having nearly the same density are impacted by a 4 mm diameter ferrite sphere. Carbon specimens 40 mm long, with a 65 mm diameter, are impacted by the sphere traveling with an impact velocity of 600-1500 m/s. The size (depth, area and volume) of the induced crater is then measured. The relationship between the static properties of the materials and the crater size is investigated. In this impact velocity region, materials having larger effective fracture energies have smaller craters and vice versa. Crater size is also effected by Young's modulus and/or hardness of the materials. The crater area is related to the size of lateral cracks. Carbons having larger dissipation energies result in craters of smaller area and volume.

paper_title.en: Debris Formation from an Aluminum Nitride Ceramic Plate by Microprojectile Impact
Formation of Diamond During Passage of a Shock Wave in a Copper/Graphite Powder Formation Process and Numerical Simulation

Debris Formation from Layered Plate Target by Microprojectile Impact
Anisotropic Heating of a Copper and Graphite Powder Mixture during an Electrical Column Explosion
Explosive gasification of aluminium nitride powder and rapid condensation of ultrasupersaturated gas in the rarefaction wave front

description.en:
The fast phenomena occurring in the Mach disc front and the rarefaction wave front behind the disc formed by a cylindrical shock technique have been investigated using AIN powders with low densities, 17-26% of the theoretical bulk value. Electron microscopy on the microstructures of the recovered samples proved that a dense medium, shock compressed in the Mach disc front, was produced, accompanied by a drastic gasification in the rarefaction wave front. The resulting high-temperature high-pressure gas contained a large quantity of plasma (molecular gas cloud), that had rapidly condensed under the steep pressure, temperature and density gradients. The gas density was calculated to be about 76-84% of the theoretical density of AIN, and it was presumed that the gasification was terminated in the order of a nanosecond, while the condensation of ultra-supersaturated gas proceeded over the time range nanoseconds to microseconds. The distribution of the component particles developed from the gas suggested the following condensation processes. At first, numerous liquid droplets developed in the molecular gas cloud. The liquid droplets increased their sizes by collision and coalescence. The agglomeration of spherical particles formed by solidification of the liquid droplets led to a great number of clusters of different sizes. Subsequently to the formation of cluster, shells with several surface structures were produced by deposition of the intercluster residual gas on the cluster surfaces. Finally, fine particles, having pyramidal, needle-like, filamental and dendritic shapes, grew via gas-solid processes. All particles obtained, except for part of shells having the cubic structure, were single crystals of AIN with the wurtzite crystal structure. © 1995 Taylor &amp
 Francis Group, LLC.

publication_name.en: Philosophical Magazine A: Physics of Condensed Matter, Structure, Defects and Mechanical Properties

paper_title.en: CHARACTERIZATION AND MODIFICATION OF AMORPHOUS-CARBON FILMS CONSISTING OF SP(2) AND SP(3) BONDS USING MAGNETO-PLASMA DYNAMIC ARC-JET

description.en: A magneto plasma dynamic are-jet (MPD arc-jet) can introduce a large energy pulse to a source gas and enable synthesis amorphous carbon films consisting of sp(2) and sp(3) bonds (hybrid amorphous carbon). The process condi tions which affect the structure and the properties of the synthesized films are described here. Homogeneous films were obtained using the MPD are-jet technique. Films were also in-situ, modified with modifier gases due to the excellent characteristics of the MPD are-jet. A substrate temperature of 200 degrees C and a bias potential of -200 V resulted in harder films. The hardness are related to the hydrogen content and chemical bond nature of the carbon in the films, Homogeneity in the deposition direction could be achieved by in-situ modification, The refractive index, hardness, and other properties of the films were controlled by this modification.
